questions.question: What is the primary definition of a food constituent?
options: Substances that add flavor to food.
Substances that provide essential nourishment for life maintenance and growth.
Substances that are only found in synthetic foods.

questions.question: What is the recommended daily intake of Vitamin D for infants and pregnant women?
For which demographic group is the protein requirement the highest (per kg body weight)?
Food constituents are classified into five major groups.
Most natural foods contain only one nutrient.
Glycogen from liver and muscles is an animal source of carbohydrates.
Dietary fiber can help prevent colon cancer.
The human body can synthesize all amino acids it needs.
Proteins provide 9 calories of energy per gram.
Fats are a more concentrated source of energy than carbohydrates.
Vitamin A from plant sources is in a preformed, readily usable state.
Vitamin D functions as a hormone in the body.
Vitamin K is produced sufficiently by bacteria in the human intestine.
Water-soluble vitamins can be stored in the body for long periods.
A deficiency in Thiamine (B1) can lead to neurological problems.
Vitamin B12 deficiency causes pernicious anemia.
Folate deficiency results in microcytic hypochromic anemia.
Osteomalacia is a condition with normal bone amount but abnormal composition.
Iron is a component of the thyroid hormones.
Excess sodium intake can contribute to edema and high blood pressure.
Dietary fiber can be digested and absorbed by the human digestive system.
Water provides energy (calories) to the body.
The recommended protein intake for a lactating woman is lower than for a healthy adult man.
